Councilmember Place 6
=====================

Councilmember Roland Goveas
---------------------------

Roland's journey took an exciting turn when he made the decision to relocate to Texas in 1992. In 1995, he started Synetics Computers Inc., (a Managed
services company) and in 1998 he settled in Richland Hills, a vibrant city that would become his home and the center of his endeavors.

In addition to his professional achievements, Roland has made significant contributions to his community. From 2011 to 2017 and again from 2018 to 2020, he served as a council member, actively participating in the governance and decision-making processes that shape the City of Richland Hills. Roland's dedication to community development was further exemplified through his involvement with various boards and his role as the chair of the City's inaugural 4
of July Hometown Parade. He has also served on the Charter Review Committee twice, demonstrating his commitment to ensuring effective governance and transparency.

* Crime Control and Prevention District (
  )

Per the City of Richland Hills
Home Rule Charter (PDF)
, the duties of City of Richland Hills councilmembers are as follows:

Sec. 6.03. - Powers and duties of City Council.

The powers and duties herein conferred upon the City Council shall include but shall not be limited to the following:

(1) To appoint and remove the City Manager, City Attorney, Municipal Judge and relief Municipal Judges, and other such employees required by state law to be appointed by the City Council.

(3) To adopt the budget of the City.

B. Certificates of obligation subject to the notice, petition and election provisions as provided within V.T.C.A, Local Government Code ยง271041, the Certificate of Obligation Act.

(5) To inquire into the conduct of any office, department, or agency of the City and make investigation as to municipal affairs.

(8) To adopt and modify the official map of the City.

(9) To regulate, license, and fix the charges or fares made by any person owning, obtaining or controlling any vehicle of any character used for carrying of passengers for hire on the public streets and alleys of the City.

(11) To fix the salaries and compensation for the non-elective City officers and employees.

(13) May regulate burial grounds, cemeteries, and crematories and condemn and close any such burial grounds, cemeteries, and crematories in the thickly settled portions of the City when public interest or public health may demand, and may regulate interment of the deceased.
